I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) proposed 
loans, and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Multi-Donor Clean 
Energy Fund1 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, all to the Democratic 
Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the Clean Energy and Network Efficiency Improvement 
Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Building for 
Clean Power Development, and if the Board approves the proposed loans and administration of 
the grant, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
2.  The  project2 includes  three  components:  (i)  transmission  infrastructure;  (ii)  network 
efficiency  improvements;  and  (iii)  pilot  solar  rooftop  power  generation  investments  in  the 
Eastern, North Central, Central, Northern, Southern, and Western provinces of the country.3  
 
II.  THE PROJECT  
A.  Rationale 
3.  Sri Lanka has achieved a substantial improvement in the energy sector, with a national 
electrification ratio of 91% in 2011 compared with 29% in 1990. The longer-term challenge for 
the country is to reduce its high dependence on expensive fossil fuel energy. The energy sector 
struggles to meet growing demand for electricity at sufficiently low cost and acceptable reliability 
levels.4 The share of thermal energy in the power generation mix has increased from 6% in 
1995 to 54% in 2011. Demand growth has been generally met by expensive oil-fired thermal 
generation, which is not the solution to the country’s energy security and environment protection 
in  the  long  term.  Diversification  of  the  generation  mix—including  from  renewable  energy 
sources, improvement of network efficiency, and supply and demand side management—can 
help to address this issue. To enable future planned power supply increases, meet growing 
demand in the regions, and integrate renewable energy sources into the grid, it is necessary to 
strengthen the transmission network, especially in conflict-affected areas of the Northern and 
Eastern provinces.5 Another challenge is to improve system reliability and reduce technical 
losses. An enhanced 33 kilovolt (kV) medium voltage network is needed to expand power 
supply in rural areas, where many poor households remain unconnected or have poor quality of 
electricity  supplies.  The  new  infrastructure  will  also  support  development  of  clean  energy. 
Improvement of transmission and distribution infrastructure will address electricity needs in the 
post-conflict areas and directly contribute to their development.6 The government intends to

institutional reforms in line with the Sri Lanka Electricity Act, 2009. 
 
4.  The project fits Sri Lanka’s national and sector priorities stated in the country’s 10-Year 
Development  Framework  of  2006.7 These  include  infrastructure  development  to  accelerate 
economic growth and narrow regional disparities, sustainable development of energy resources, 
and access to and reliable delivery of electricity services at competitive prices. The framework is 
based on the government’s National Energy Policy and Strategies. The government updated 
this development framework in 2010.8 The updated framework has a comprehensive sector 
development road map, a long-term investment program, and policy and reform measures. In 
particular, the new government strategy aims to (i) increase power supply capacity to about 
3,500 megawatts (MW) by 2012 and 6,400 MW by 2020 and reduce the generation cost by 
adding aggregate base load capacity of about 2,000 MW of three coal-fired plants; (ii) increase 
the share in grid energy supply from nonconventional renewable energy sources from 4.1% in 
2007 to 7.0% by 2012, 10.0% by 2016, and 20.0% by 2020; and (iii) reduce the total technical 
and commercial losses in the network from 14.6% in 2009 to 14.0% by 2012, 13.0% by 2016, 
and 12.0% by 2020. 
 
5.  The project is consistent with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership 
strategy for Sri Lanka.9 It will support sustainable development of the energy sector in line with 
the national and sector priorities.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The project will contribute to a reliable, adequate, and affordable power supply for 
sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction. The outcome will be increased clean power 
supply, and improved efficiency and reliability in the delivery of electricity.

9.  The government has requested (i) a loan of $100 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources (OCR), (ii) a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR19,994,000 from the Asian 
Development Fund (ADF), and (iii) a grant of $1.5 million from the Multi-Donor CEF under 
CEFPF to help finance the project. The ADF loan will finance transmission infrastructure in the 
Northern province. The transmission and distribution network efficiency improvement will be 
financed from the OCR loan. The solar rooftop power generation pilot subprojects will be 
financed by the grant and a credit line of $1.5 million from the OCR loan.  
 
10.  The OCR loan will have a 20-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, a straight-
line repayment method, an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, 
the interest and other charges during construction to be capitalized in the loan,12 and such other 
terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements.13 The government has 
provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending 
facility based on these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its 
own independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
11.  The ADF loan will have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an annual 
interest rate of 1.0% during the grace period and 1.5% thereafter, and such other terms and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements.

Development.15 CEB and SEA will be the implementing agencies. ADB will provide $0.9 million 
in grant financing from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV).

18.  The TA will examine the potential for clean energy generation from renewable sources. It 
will also study and prepare (i) system stability and network planning; (ii) a medium-term master 
plan for renewable energy; (iii) a master plan for a wind park; (iv) public–private partnership

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical  
 
19.  A technical assessment demonstrated the prepared technology to be consistent with 
best practice. The investment plan estimates, and the operating cost and structure once the 
investments are made, were examined and found to be appropriate.  The investment proposal 
fits  the  specifications  associated  with  the  current  asset  base  for  the  transmission  and 
distribution network in the project areas. The investments may not place an undue burden on 
CEB. However, CEB needs to improve significantly its financial base, financial performance, 
operating systems, and overall efficiency levels. An independent study is planned to tackle 
these shortcomings. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
20.  The economic internal rate of return16 was calculated by comparing with- and without-
project  scenarios.  Detailed  cost–benefit  calculations  confirm  the  economic  viability  and 
sustainability of the investments. The economic internal rate of return is 12.16%. A sensitivity 
and risk analysis demonstrates a robust economic performance. 
 
21.  The financial internal rate of return (FIRR)17 is 10.99%. Financial viability was examined 
by comparing the incremental costs and benefits on a with- and without-investment basis. The 
weighted average cost of capital was calculated for each subproject and for the overall project. 
Financial viability was assessed by comparing the weighted average cost of capital to the FIRR 
for each subproject and for the aggregated project. The sensitivity of the FIRR to adverse 
movements in the underlying assumptions was also assessed and found to be robust.  
 
C.  Governance 
 
22.  CEB is a vertically integrated utility delinked from the regulatory framework. The Sri 
Lanka Electricity Act, 2009 encourages efficiency improvements of CEB by regulating each of 
its  six  functional  business  units  (FBUs).  The  2009  Act  empowered  the  Public  Utilities 
Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), an independent regulator for the energy and water sectors 
established under the PUCSL Act, 2002, to regulate electricity supply industry. PUCSL started 
regulating each FBU separately and has issued individual licenses for that purpose. Financial 
accounts are segregated to allow each FBU to operate as a profit center, and a transfer pricing 
scheme between FBUs is in place. The CEB board delegates to the heads of each FBU day-to-
day  management  decision  making.  Subsequent  to  the  introduction  of  the  2009  Act,  ADB 
approved  a  Clean  Energy  and  Access  Improvement  Project18 in  2009,  which,  along  with 
investments in physical infrastructure, was designed to bring about sector reforms. PUCSL

23.  CEB has the necessary capacity to undertake the project. CEB was the implementing 
agency for past ADB-financed projects. It has also managed investments funded by other 
development partners. A financial management assessment of CEB concluded that it can fulfill 
ADB’s fiduciary requirements for the project. CEB regularly faces cash shortfalls because of low 
tariffs and expensive power generation and it has expensive short-term loans. Both of these 
shortcomings  need  to  be  corrected.  The  government  remains  committed  to  energy  sector 
reforms. Under the 2009 Act, all tariffs must reflect costs; the Treasury will bear the cost of any 
subsidy approved by the government. In March 2008, the government introduced a new tariff 
structure that increased average retail tariffs by 30%. The government has also restructured a 
portion of CEB’s long-term debt. The tariff order issued by PUCSL in January 2011 increased 
the  average  electricity  tariff  by  about  8%.  In  February  2012,  PUCSL  implemented  a  fuel 
adjustment formula for certain customer categories. With the introduction of low-cost generation, 
it is expected that it will be possible to achieve cost recovery from 2017. Details of CEB’s 
financial management assessment are available in the project administration manual and in the 
assessment of CEB’s past financial performance and projections.19 
 
24.  SEA has received considerable capacity development  assistance from development 
partners, including ADB20 and Japan International Cooperation Agency, and will be undertaking 
technical due diligence of applications for the solar rooftop power generation pilot subprojects. 
The agency can manage the proposed grant and credit line. 
 
25.  All  procurement  under  the  project  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Recruitment of consultants will 
be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). Open competitive bidding will be followed. An oversight role by ADB will ensure 
integrity in procurement and implementation activities. CEB and SEA maintain a project website 
that will be updated regularly and will include (i) bidding procedures, bidders, and contract 
awards; (ii) use of the funds disbursed under the project; and (iii) physical progress. ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
government,  MOPE,  CEB,  and  SEA.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual.

E.  Safeguards 
 
  1.  Social Safeguards 
 
27.  None of the project components will have any significant social safeguard impacts. The 
transmission and distribution lines primarily cross public and unused lands. Where croplands 
are affected, adequate compensation will be paid. Project construction will be carried out during 
the crop off-seasons. Where new grid substations are built on commercial and private lands, 
adequate compensation will be paid to their owners. The project is classified category B for 
involuntary  resettlement  impacts.  CEB  prepared  a  resettlement  plan  for  the  transmission 
infrastructure  and  transmission  and  distribution  efficiency  improvement  components.22 The 
project is classified category C for impacts on indigenous peoples.  
 
  2.  Environmental Safeguards 
 
28.  CEB and SEA have prepared initial environmental examinations23 for their components 
and held public consultations. During construction and operation, steps will be taken to minimize 
environmental impacts. CEB has observed the route-selection criteria in the national regulations 
and has adopted best environmental practices. Adequate provisions have been made for the 
environmental mitigation measures, monitoring requirements, and their associated costs in the 
environmental management plans (EMPs) prepared for each subproject. CEB has sufficient 
capacity to implement the safeguard measures incorporated in the EMPs. Mitigation measures 
related to construction and specified in the EMPs will be incorporated into civil works contracts. 
The contractors will have primary responsibility for implementing the mitigation measures during 
construction,  but  CEB  will  be  responsible  for  and  periodically  report  to  ADB  on  overall 
implementation of its site-specific EMPs. CEB and SEA will adhere to ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement (2009) and local and government environmental regulations. The project is classified 
category B for environment. 
 
3.  Climate Change Impact 
 
29.  The project is expected to have considerable positive impacts on climate change. Its 
renewable energy intervention will bring solar power generation to the grid, which is equivalent 
to avoiding about 1,286 tons of carbon dioxide emissions per year. An average reduction of 
about 55,500 tons of carbon dioxide emissions per year may be achieved through technical loss 
reduction from the improved energy efficiency of the transmission and distribution lines for 
2016–2036. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
30.  The  potential  governance  risk  stems  from  CEB  having  insufficient  cash  to  fund  its 
operations because of (i) an increase in fuel oil costs and reliance on expensive thermal 
electricity generation, (ii) delays in commissioning less costly generating capacity, and (iii) tariffs 
set below the cost of supply. The potential risks to project implementation include unexpected

reduce the cost of generation; and (ii) close supervision by the steering committee and ADB, 
timely project implementation, and advance contracting. Major risks and mitigating measures

V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
31.  The  government  and  MOPE  have  assured  ADB  that  project  implementation  shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. The government, MOPE, CEB, and 
SEA have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the draft 
loan and project agreements. 
 
32.  Disbursement of the credit line for the solar rooftop power generation pilot will be subject 
to the following conditions: 
 
(i)  approval of the criteria for the selection of private sector solar power developers 
and participating financial institution(s) by the government and ADB; 
(ii)  selection of an eligible participating financial institution(s)25 satisfactory to ADB; 
and 
(iii)  execution of a subsidiary financing agreement (and delivery of legal opinion 
thereon)  between  SEA,  eligible  participating  financial  institution(s),  and  the 
government in form and substance satisfactory to ADB.

10 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
 
(i)  the loan of $100,000,000 to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for 
the  Clean  Energy  and  Network  Efficiency  Improvement  Project  from  ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 
20  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
and project agreements presented to the Board;  
(ii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR19,994,000 to the Democratic 
Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the Clean Energy and Network Efficiency 
Improvement  Project  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  with  an  interest 
charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and 
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board; and 
(iii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,500,000  to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the  Clean 
Energy and Network Efficiency Improvement Project, to be provided by the Multi-
Donor  Clean  Energy  Fund  under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing  Partnership 
Facility.
